Award.AwardTitle: Conflict and constraint in multicellular life cycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This work will explore two fundamental questions about multicellularity. First, are the early stages of development necessarily the hardest to change? This seems true in animals, but the project will test whether this pattern is general, using genomic data in a very different multicellular system, a social amoeba in which is normally a single-celled eukaryote, but upon starvation aggregates and differentiates into a structure with reproductive spores and sterile stalk cells. The second question is, how do multicellular organisms protect themselves from mutant cell lineages that replicate too fast? The project will use the novel strategy of constructing pseudo-organisms with artificial life cycles. By allowing these to evolve and monitoring cellular cooperation, the project will isolate factors that maintain multicellularity.


The most advanced organisms on earth, including people, animals, and plants, are all multicellular. Yet there is much that we do not understand about how and why multicellularity works. By focusing an unusual developmental system, the project will test how events at one time or place in development affect and constrain events at other times and places. They will also conduct the first rigorous tests of what life cycles protect against conflict among cells - cancer being a prominent example. The project will contribute to scientific training and will reach out to the public via websites, science cafes, and events for K-12 students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conflict and constraint in multicellular life cycles

 

When one thinks of how human bodies are built, one may think of fingers and toes, or the way that muscles and tendons are attached to bones and together allow walking, running, and swiming. There are also organs, heart, liver, stomach, lung and more, that do their different physiological jobs to keep oxygen flowing to tissues, break down food, or create babies. But there is a level that is much more fundamental than these that  is hardly ever considered. It is that humans are made up of many cells, over 37 trillion human cells, actually. Understanding how all these cells stay in place, grow to the right size and number and no more or fewer, and how they all work for the good of the body they are in is one of the great questions of biology.

It is also one of the biggest challenges because the disease that results when a cell line gets out of order and loses its limit of place or number is called cancer. There is a lot to be learned from studying the specifics of any one case of a cell line overstepping its boundaries in a given cancer. But to understand the general principles behind this sort of disruption it is necessary to study a system where the limits are not predetermined in the way they are in most existing multicellular bodies.

For this, the investigators turned to the amoeba because it is a basic kind of cell that shares many characteristics and about 2,000 genes with our own more limited cells. In particular, they used a social amoeba because it has both a solitary stage and a social one in which there is a division into several different cell types. Because its multicellular body arises from formerly independent amoebae, they can ask questions about that process. They created something called pseudoorganisms in which they mimic traits of existing multicellular organisms like ourselves to see what the impact is on the multicellular organism and cellular proliferation.

At this point it is important to say that they do not propose to cure diseases like cancer. They do propose to understand them better and this is important. Their basic methods have to do with imposing structure on groups of cells, just as being in a pancreas or a lung imposes certain kinds of structure. In this case, the structures have to do with boundaries for the tissue and whether they are broad or narrow. They have also looked at the differences between growing out from a central place as compared to growing out from many places. They have compared original growth to dispersal, as happens when cancer metastasizes.

They have discovered several very interesting properties of synthetic multicellular organisms. One of the earliest things they found is that growth mutants are extremely common. This was best seen by putting a lot of cells in the middle of a plate and letting them grow out from the center. Suddenly there would be a wedge of faster dividing cells taking over the new ground, just as a cancer would. It made them wonder at the comparative rarity of cancer in human bodies and understand how many limits to growth there are. On the plates, one of these limits is a physical one, a lack of new places to invade.

To look at this, they used 3D printing and made chambers of different dimensions. If a proliferation mutant cannot grow into the neighboring chamber, it cannot take the resources from the cells already there. They also found that an important kind of control involves relatedness among the cells. Even when the first population of cells is genetically identical, a new mutant will not be the same at the mutated locus. If the new mutant mostly interacts with other new mutants of the same type, its growth will be limited.

This project involved many students of all levels. An undergraduate did all the 3D printing of chambers in which to construct pseudoorganisms once the investigators moved beyond the traditional Petri plates. The investigators and their students introduced high school students to the area with a series of activities. The investigators started a new class to teach research methods. They presented their results at talks and poster sessions at many places across the country.

Cancer is fundamentally a disease of cell proliferation and movement. When researchers study these factors in existing multicellular organisms, it is in the context of many existing limits that may or may not be apparent. By studying how cell lineages arise, move, multiply, and compete with other lineages, the scientists and their students hope to get at some of the fundamental principles behind both controlling cells and how that control breaks down.
